President Donald Trump announced that his talks with Chinese President Xi Jinping regarding the TikTok deal were “productive”. He also said that the two leaders will meet again at the APEC Summit, which is scheduled for November in South Korea, and that he will make a visit to China early next year.“I just completed a very productive call with President Xi of China. We made progress on many very important issues including Trade, Fentanyl, the need to bring the War between Russia and Ukraine to an end, and the approval of the TikTok Deal,” he said in a post on his own social media platform Truth Social.Trump said that both the leaders also talked about “trade, fentanyl, the need to bring the War between Russia and Ukraine to an end.”“I also agreed with President Xi that we would meet at the APEC Summit in South Korea, that I would go to China in the early part of next year, and that President Xi would, likewise, come to the United States at an appropriate time. The call was a very good one, we will be speaking again by phone, appreciate the TikTok approval, and both look forward to meeting at APEC!”In a recent interview with Fox News ahead of his call with Jinping, Trump said that the two sides were “very close to deals on all of it.”He even voiced confidence in his ties with China and confirmed, “It sounds like they’ve approved TikTok.”Apart from this, Trump also emphasised the app's significance and its contribution to his Presidential election campaign.“I like TikTok. Article Title: Samsung may bring first tri-fold phone to US this year: Report
Article Text:
Representative image

“A much larger screen than before”

Betting on foldables





Samsung is considering releasing its upcoming “tri-fold” smartphone in the United States later this year, marking the first time such a device would be available in the market, according to a CNN Business report. Samsung is still weighing which markets to launch the device in, but the US is part of those discussions, a person familiar with the company’s plans told the publication. Notably, Samsung has often limited new product lines to certain regions, such as South Korea and China. For instance, last year it released the Galaxy Z Fold 6 SE only in those countries.Chinese rival Huawei already sells a tri-folding phone, but the company does not operate in the US market. If Samsung proceeds, it would make the device the first tri-fold smartphone available to American consumers.The tri-fold is expected to fold in two places, offering a display larger than Samsung’s current foldables. “I think what we’re seeing is a bit more of a return to life before (the smartphone),” said Drew Blackard, senior vice president of mobile product management for Samsung Electronics America, in an interview with CNN.“When older cell phones had different forms and people wanted a variety of options.”Minseok Kang, Samsung’s global head of smartphone product planning, told the publication that the 2025 launch timeline is on track. Kang described the new form factor as the next step in a product strategy that has already seen strong demand for the Galaxy Z Flip and Z Fold, which together saw a 25% increase in preorders compared to their predecessors. The Galaxy Z Fold 7, Samsung’s latest foldable, unfolds to an eight-inch screen.Samsung has teased tri-folding prototypes at trade shows, including the Flex G and Flex S concepts. The upcoming phone would mark the first time those designs are translated into a commercial product.“I think… the exciting part is getting it out into the wild and then ultimately seeing what different users are attracted to,” Blackard told CNN.Analysts say the tri-fold could remain a niche, high-priced device like Samsung’s existing Fold lineup. But it could help the company stand apart from rivals, especially as Apple prepares to launch its iPhone Air this week and reportedly develops its own foldable phone for 2026.
Article Summary: The tri-fold is expected to fold in two places, offering a display larger than Samsung’s current foldables. Samsung is still weighing which markets to launch the device in, but the US is part of those discussions, a person familiar with the company's plans said.

Article Title: SoftBank Vision Fund restructures, lays off 20% to double down on AI
Article Text:
From venture capital to AI infrastructure



Leaner team, sharper focus







In a strategic move Softbank group will reportedly layoff 20% of its Vision Fund workforce. As reported by Reuters, the internal memo the will is firing 20% of its workforce form the Vision Fund division. This move of the company marks the return to founder Masayoshi Son’s signature high-risk, high-reward investment style—this time focused squarely on artificial intelligence. As per Reuters, the fresh round of layoffs will impact 60 employees of the global team. Unlike previous reductions triggered by mounting losses, this round follows the fund’s strongest quarterly performance since June 2021, buoyed by gains in public holdings such as Nvidia and Coupang. “We continually adjust the organization to best execute our long-term strategy—making bold, high-conviction investments in AI and breakthrough technologies,” a Vision Fund spokesperson told Reuters.This restructuring at Softbank signals a decisive shift away from Vision Fund’s sprawling startup portfolio toward capital-intensive AI infrastructure. As per the report, Softbank founder Son is now moving the resources into a handful of massive bets such as $30 billion investment in OpenAI, $6,5 billion acquisition of chip designer Ampere Computing and $500 billion in Stargate project which is a joint venture of OpenAI and Oracle.The report also suggests the Son is also pursuing $1 trillion AI industrial park in collaboration with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.As per Reuters report, the fresh round of layoffs indicate that with fewer teams and narrower focus, the Vision Fund will need less number of investment advisers. At its peak in 2020, the fund employed 474 people; today, that number has shrunk by nearly 40%.The layoffs also reflect on Son’s belief that the next wave of tech will be driven by AI models, semiconductors, and data infrastructure—not broad venture capital plays. SoftBank has already taken stakes in Intel, Nvidia, and acquired chip firms Graphcore and Ampere Computing, aiming to build a full-stack AI ecosystem.
Article Summary: Softbank group will reportedly layoff 20% of its Vision Fund workforce. This move marks the return to founder Masayoshi Son’s signature high-risk, high- reward investment style. At its peak in 2020, the fund employed 474 people; today, that number has shrunk by nearly 40%.

A suspected North Korean hacking group has used ChatGPT to create a deepfake of a South Korean military ID card, a report claims. According to cybersecurity researchers, these fake IDs was reportedly used to make a phishing attempt more credible by linking to malware that could extract data from the recipient's device. The cyber-espionage unit, which researchers have dubbed Kimsuky, is suspected of being sponsored by North Korea and has been linked to other spying efforts against South Korean targets. The US Department of Homeland Security previously stated that Kimsuky is likely tasked by the North Korean regime with a global intelligence-gathering mission. The details were published in a report by the South Korean cybersecurity firm Genians.During their investigation into forged identification documents, Genians researchers tested ChatGPT. While the system initially refused to generate a government ID (which is illegal under South Korean law) however, adjusting the prompt allowed the restriction to be bypassed.Mun Chong-hyun, director at Genians said that the broader trend shows how attackers are turning to AI for tasks such as planning attacks, developing malware, creating hacking tools, and impersonating recruiters.In July, cybersecurity firm Genians shared its latest findings on signs of suspected North Korean operatives using AI in intelligence-gathering.Later on, in August, Anthropic reported that North Korean hackers had leveraged its Claude Code tool to secure remote jobs at US Fortune 500 tech companies. The AI system assisted them in crafting fake identities, passing coding tests, and even delivering technical work once hired.Earlier, in February, the company said it had banned accounts linked to North Korea that were using its service to generate fraudulent resumes, cover letters, and social media content to support recruitment schemes.Recent phishing attempts targeted South Korean journalists, researchers, and human rights activists focusing on North Korea. Emails appeared to come from an address ending in .mli.kr, mimicking a South Korean military domain. The number of victims remains unclear.US officials have long accused North Korea of running cyber operations, cryptocurrency theft, and IT contracting schemes to collect intelligence and generate revenue. Washington alleges that the funds support Pyongyang’s efforts to evade sanctions and advance its nuclear weapons program.

Article Title: US and China reach “framework” deal to save TikTok from ban
Article Text:
Trump administration claims victory ahead of looming deadline

Questions remain over algorithm control and congressional approval





The United States and China announced they have reached a "framework" agreement to transfer TikTok to US-controlled ownership, potentially averting a ban of the popular social media app just days before a September 17 deadline. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent confirmed the preliminary deal during trade talks in Madrid, saying President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping will finalize the agreement in a Friday phone call.The framework would shift ownership of TikTok's US operations away from Chinese parent company ByteDance to American investors, addressing national security concerns that have dominated the app's future for years. While Bessent declined to reveal commercial terms, calling it a deal "between two private parties," he emphasized the agreement protects US security interests while preserving what Chinese negotiators consider the app's cultural characteristics.Trump celebrated the breakthrough on Truth Social, writing that "a deal was also reached on a 'certain' company that young people in our Country very much wanted to save."The announcement comes after months of negotiations and three deadline extensions since Trump took office, with the current ban scheduled to take effect Wednesday if no agreement is reached.Chinese trade negotiator Li Chenggang confirmed the two sides reached a "basic framework consensus" on resolving TikTok-related issues through cooperation. However, he warned the US against continued "suppression" of Chinese companies while seeking Chinese accommodation on American concerns.Critical details remain unresolved, including whether ByteDance will transfer control of TikTok's valuable recommendation algorithm that drives user engagement. Chinese officials previously expressed reluctance to export the algorithm technology, which Beijing considers strategically sensitive. Wang Jingtao from China's cyberspace regulator suggested the deal could involve licensing intellectual property rights rather than full transfer.Any final agreement may require approval from Congress, which passed bipartisan legislation in 2024 requiring ByteDance to divest TikTok or face a ban due to national security fears. The law, upheld by the Supreme Court, prohibits companies from "foreign adversary" countries from owning more than 20 percent of the platform.Industry analysts expect Oracle co-founder Larry Ellison, a Trump ally whose company currently hosts TikTok's US data, to lead the American investor group. TikTok serves approximately 170 million US users, making it one of the most significant social media platforms in the country.
Article Summary: The United States and China announced they have reached a "framework" agreement to transfer TikTok to US-controlled ownership. The agreement could avert a ban of the popular social media app just days before a September 17 deadline. Article Title: “Time is too precious”: Warren Buffett explains why he won’t upgrade his 11-year-old car
Article Text:
Time over money



A lesson in simplicity







Most of the billionaires often flaunt their luxury lifestyle by showing off their expensive cars as a status symbol, however, Warren Buffett does not believe in this show off. The billionaire loves his 11-year old car and treats it like a kitchen appliance. At 94, the legendary investor drives a 2014 Cadillac XTS—complete with hail damage—because, in his words, “a half a day I don’t want to give up” is too steep a price for car shopping. Buffett’s approach towards not buying a car is not new. At the Berkshire Hathaway shareholders meeting in 2001, Buffett explained that simplicity and safety matters the most to him and not style. His present Cadillac, which was purchased by his daughter Susie Buffett, reflects that ethos. Susie purchased the car from Huber Cadillac in Omaha, posing as a regular customer. Later Buffett praised the dealership in a letter to GM CEO Mary Barra for treating her fairly—without knowing she was buying for one of the world’s richest men.Buffett views of still using the 11-year old car is rooted in his philosophy that time is the most valuable asset. “If I could write a check in 30 seconds and be in the same position I’m in now with a newer car, I’d be glad to do it this afternoon,” he once said.“But I don’t like to trade away when there’s really no benefit to me at all.”Every year he drives around 3,500 miles a year and despite some occasional nudges from his daughter to upgrade, he remains content. To Buffett, cars are about utility, safety, and efficiency—not prestige.As reported by Cox Automotive’s 2023 Car Buyer Journey Study, most of the Americans spend around 12 to 14 hours in buying a car. Buffett’s decision of delegating the task to her daughter underscores the belief that those hours can be spent in reading, investing and thinking.His investing philosophy mirrors his driving habits: buy quality, hold long, and avoid unnecessary churn. “I’m totally happy with the car,” he said in 2001—and he’s still proving it today, behind the wheel of a Cadillac that’s weathered more than just Nebraska hailstorms.
Article Summary: Warren Buffett drives an 11-year-old Cadillac XTS. The billionaire believes that time is the most valuable asset. He drives around 3,500 miles a year and despite occasional nudges from his daughter to upgrade, he remains content. To Buffett, cars are about utility, safety, and efficiency—not prestige.

Article Title: Intel CEO Lip-Bu Tan calls Nvidia’s Jensen Huang a “Good Friend” as $5 billion partnership sends Intel stock soaring
Article Text:
A partnership of strengths



Huang: AI is the new industrial revolution



Investment details and market impact







In a landmark moment for the semiconductor industry, Intel and Nvidia have announced partnership to develop custom chips and next-generation computing systems. The deal between the two chip manufactures includes $5 billion investment by Nvidia. After this announcement the Intel shares witnessed a 22.77% surge which closed at $30.57 — marking its sharpest rally of the year. After this announcement, Intel CEO Lip-Bu Tan also praised the collaboration and described Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang as a ‘Good Friend’. “Excited to team up with my good friend Jensen to jointly develop multiple generations of custom data center and PC products,” Tan posted on X.The partnership will see Intel make custom x86 CPUs which will be tailored for Nvidia’s AI infrastructure. Along with this, the company will also build system-on-chip (SoC) solutions for PCs that integrate Nvidia RTX GPU chiplets. Also, Nvidia’s NVLink technology will work as a bridge between the two platforms and enable seamless performance. Tan also stressed in the fact that Intel’s legacy in x86 architecture and its manufacturing scale as key assets in the collaboration.“Our collaboration brings together the best of Intel and Nvidia to benefit customers—and shows how vital x86 architecture and NVLink will be in shaping the future of AI infrastructure and personal computing,” he said.Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang also praised the alliance and called it transformative and a foundational step in the evolution of computing. “AI is powering a new industrial revolution and reinventing every layer of the computing stack—from silicon to systems to software,” Huang said.He further added that combining Nvidia’s CUDA platform with Intel’s CPU would enable a foundation for the next era of computing.Nvidia is investing $5 billion in its struggling former takeover target and rescue Intel through a strategic chip partnership. The deal announced sees Nvidia purchasing Intel stock at $23.28 per share—a 6.5% discount—while the companies collaborate on PC and data center processors. Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang has now explained why he decided to bet on Intel. As reported by Business Insider, Huang revealed that he still has confidence in the chipmaker’s turnaround. “We’re delighted to have invested in Intel, and the return on that investment is going to be fantastic,” Huang said at a Thursday press conference.
Article Summary: Intel and Nvidia have announced partnership to develop custom chips and next- generation computing systems. The deal between the two chip manufactures includes $5 billion investment by Nvidia. Intel shares witnessed a 22.77% surge which closed at $30.57 — marking its sharpest rally of the year.

Article Title: What Intel isn't saying about its Arc GPUs after the Nvidia’s $5 billion investment
Article Text:

Intel's carefully worded statements about Arc GPU survival raise red flags about the graphics division's true future as Nvidia's $5 billion investment reshapes the partnership landscape. While Intel publicly insists its Arc graphics cards will continue alongside the new Nvidia partnership, the company's evasive language suggests a more complicated reality behind closed doors.Intel told PCWorld that "the collaboration is complementary to Intel's roadmap and Intel will continue to have GPU product offerings"—but notably avoided specifics about timeline, investment levels, or long-term commitment to discrete graphics development.The carefully parsed statement sidesteps critical questions: Will Intel maintain full funding for Arc development when Nvidia can provide superior graphics solutions? How does continuing expensive GPU research make financial sense for a company that recently cut thousands of jobs and divested multiple divisions?Industry observers note the messaging feels deliberately vague. Terms like "complementary" and "continue to have GPU product offerings" leave significant wiggle room for scaling back operations or eventually phasing out Arc entirely.Yesterday's Nvidia partnership announcement revealed that RTX graphics chiplets will be integrated directly into Intel processors, potentially making standalone Arc cards redundant for most consumers. The collaboration explicitly targets AMD's growing market share through combined CPU-GPU products—exactly the strategy Intel's Arc division has been pursuing independently.The timing raises additional concerns. Intel's Arc B580 recently gained positive reviews, and upcoming Battlemage and Celestial architectures showed promise. Yet the Nvidia deal emerged just as Arc momentum was building, suggesting internal strategic shifts that Intel isn't publicly acknowledging.What Intel isn't saying may be more revealing than its official statements: whether Arc GPUs represent a continued priority or simply existing inventory and contractual obligations playing out while Nvidia assumes graphics responsibilities.The truth likely lies in Intel's upcoming quarterly guidance and R&D allocation decisions.

During the conversation, he said:“AI should be democratized for everyone. There should be no person who is left behind, it’s not sensible to me that someone should be left behind on electricity or the internet of the next level of technology”.During the same conversation, Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang praised Google Gemini’s latest AI tool – Nano Banana. “How could anyone not love Nano Banana? Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella revealed during an internal town hall that he's "haunted" by Digital Equipment Corporation (DEC), a once-dominant computer company that disappeared after missing critical technology shifts. Speaking to employees last week, Nadella used DEC's downfall as a cautionary tale about Microsoft's own survival in the AI era, according to The Verge.DEC ruled the minicomputer world in the early 1970s with its PDP series but became irrelevant after making strategic errors, including betting on its proprietary VAX architecture instead of emerging RISC technology. The company faced fierce competition from IBM and others, ultimately leading to its demise. Nadella's first computer was ironically a VAX machine, and he had once dreamed of working at DEC."Our industry is full of case studies of companies that were great once, that just disappeared," Nadella told employees, acknowledging that "some of the biggest businesses we've built might not be as relevant going forward."The CEO's comments came as employee morale hits "all-time lows," with workers describing Microsoft as feeling "colder, more rigid, and lacking in empathy."The company has conducted multiple rounds of layoffs, including 9,000 job cuts in July, as part of what Nadella calls "renewal" for the AI transition.Nadella admitted the leadership team "can do better" but provided few specifics on addressing cultural concerns. The Verge reports that dozens of employees have expressed similar sentiments about the company's deteriorating workplace atmosphere.Microsoft previously missed the mobile revolution, which Bill Gates called his "greatest mistake ever." Now, with AI potentially threatening core products like Office suite—which generates one-fifth of annual revenue—Nadella warns that "some of the margin that we love today might not be there tomorrow.""All the categories that we may have even loved for 40 years may not matter," he cautioned, emphasising that companies must earn their right to exist daily by providing socially useful marketplace value. The specter of DEC serves as his constant reminder of what happens when tech giants fail to adapt.
Article Summary: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella used Digital Equipment Corporation's downfall as a cautionary tale about Microsoft's own survival in the AI era. It is producing its own, and intends to compete globally in the semiconductor market.”In the post, he continues saying that while Nvidia still has a substantial lead, “but Huawei is using its networking prowess to remain competitive”.“In particular, Huawei compensates for weaker individual chips by clustering more chips together,” David Sacks said.In the X post, Sacks said that it is time for the Trump administration to “update its assumptions with regard to export controls.” He urged the government to allow US chip companies to sell the “American technology stack abroad, albeit with security requirements, else we forfeit the AI race to China”.“If we refuse to do business with a country, we push it into China’s arms,” he warned.“The question of what we sell China will always be complicated, and there’s room for a wide range of opinions on that. But the question of whether we sell to the rest of the world, especially our friends and allies, should be an easy one,” he further warned.“Excessive bureaucratic delays are a gift for Huawei, which will fill out purchase orders as American companies fill out forms. The hawkish position with respect to China is to help American companies win the AI race, not to help Huawei create a Digital Silk Road,” he concluded.
Article Summary: David Sacks recently shared a post on X, urging the Trump administration to update export control policies. In the post, the AI Czar highlighted two incidents from the recent past to make his case. One such incident was Huawei introducing a new chip to rival US chipmaker Nvidia. The other included the Chinese government instruction to the Chinese companies to stop buying certain Nvidia AI chips.

Article Title: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang explains $5 billion bet on struggling Intel: “The return will be fantastic”
Article Text:
A strategic alliance amid political turbulence



SoftBank committed $2 billion

The U.S. government announced a 9.9% stake

Now, Nvidia joins with a $5 billion stake, estimated to represent 4% ownership

How Nvidia became the AI king Intel never saw coming

Expanding into the PC market





Nvidia is investing $5 billion in its struggling former takeover target and rescue Intel through a strategic chip partnership. The deal announced sees Nvidia purchasing Intel stock at $23.28 per share—a 6.5% discount—while the companies collaborate on PC and data center processors. Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang has now explained why he decided to bet on Intel. As reported by Business Insider, Huang revealed that he still has confidence in the chipmaker’s turnaround. “We’re delighted to have invested in Intel, and the return on that investment is going to be fantastic,” Huang said at a Thursday press conference.This partnership will witness Intel integrate Nvidia’s GPU technology into its upcoming AI-powered PCs. On the other hand, Nvidia will adopt Intel’s x86 CPUs for its data centers. This will mark a shift in Nvidia’s sourcing strategy as the company relied on AMD and ARM for the CPUs. “We’re going to become a very large customer of Intel CPUs,” Huang added.This announcement from Nvidia comes at a time of political scrutiny of Intel which includes recent calls from US President Donald Trump for Intel CEO Lip-Bu Tan’s resignation over alleged conflicts of interest.However, later Trump reversed the course and the episode drew attention to Intel’s challenges and its importance to U.S. industrial policy.Following the reversal, Intel attracted a wave of investment:Some analysts suggest Nvidia’s move aligns with Washington’s push to bolster domestic chip production and reduce reliance on China. “Partnering with a US-backed Intel strengthens Nvidia’s alignment with Washington’s industrial policy,” noted Brad Gastwirth of Circular Technology.Back in 2005, then-Intel CEO Paul Otellini pitched acquiring Nvidia to his board, recognizing that graphics chips might revolutionise data centers. Directors balked at the unprecedented price tag and Intel's poor acquisition track record, instead backing an internal project called Larrabee that burned hundreds of millions before collapsing in 2009.Nvidia seized the moment Intel missed. While Intel clung to traditional processors, Nvidia anticipated the AI revolution, developing specialised chips perfect for machine learning before ChatGPT made headlines. When tech giants raced to build AI infrastructure, they turned to Nvidia's ready-made solutions.Today, Nvidia approaches $200 billion in annual revenue—soon earning more each quarter than Intel generates yearly. Its data center business alone dwarfs entire chip companies.Huang’s investment of $5 billion also positions Nvidia to expand beyond its core GPU business into the personal computing space. On the other hand, Intel will get access to Nvidia’s AI capabilities. Intel’s stocks also surged by 23% reflecting investor optimism.
Article Summary: N Nvidia is investing $5 billion in its struggling former takeover target and rescue Intel through a strategic chip partnership. The deal announced sees Nvidia purchasing Intel stock at $23.28 per share—a 6.5% discount. This partnership will witness Intel integrate Nvidia’s GPU technology into its upcoming AI-powered PCs.

Article Title: US embassy’s ‘plain and straight’ message to visa applicants: Anyone involved in illegal drug trade will…
Article Text:
What is Fentanyl

Indian businessmen’s visa revoked by US





The US Embassy in India has revoked the visa of an Indian executive and family over involvement in trafficking of controlled substances, allegedly fentanyl precursors. In a post on X, the embassy said “Stopping the flow of fentanyl and its precursors into the United States is one of our highest priorities. ” “We have revoked visas for company executives and family for the unlawful involvement in controlled substance trafficking, including fentanyl,” the embassy added.In the post, the embassy further warned that “those who facilitate the flow of illicit drugs into our country will not gain access to it”. In simple words, anyone involved in the trade of illegal drugs will be denied visa to the country.Fentanyl is a powerful synthetic opioid used to treat severe pain. It is up to 100 times stronger than morphine and is prescribed in controlled medical settings for cancer patients and post-surgery cases. The drug is available as patches, injections and lozenges.Illegally manufactured fentanyl has become a global concern. It is often mixed with heroin, cocaine or fake pills, sometimes without the user’s knowledge. Even a small dose can be fatal. Health agencies worldwide have linked fentanyl to a sharp rise in overdose deaths, especially in the United States and Canada.Revoking and subsequently denying visa for certain business executives and corporate leadership based on involvement in trafficking fentanyl precursors, US embassy said that these actions are taken under section 221(i), section 212(a)(2)(C), and 214(b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act.As a result of this, these individuals and close family members may be ineligible for travel to the United States.Chargé d’affaires Jorgan Andrews said “The U.S. Embassy in New Delhi remains steadfast in its commitment to combating illicit drug trafficking. Individuals and organizations involved in the illegal production and trafficking of drugs to the United States, along with their families, will face consequences that may include being denied access to the United States”.In its press release, the US embassy also thanked Indian government for the cooperation. “We are grateful to our counterparts in the Government of India for their close cooperation to combat this shared challenge. Only by working together will our two governments address this transnational threat and keep both our people safe from illicit drugs,” it said.
Article Summary: Fentanyl is a powerful synthetic opioid used to treat severe pain. It is up to 100 times stronger than morphine and is prescribed in controlled medical settings for cancer patients and post-surgery cases. Health agencies worldwide have linked fentanyl to a sharp rise in overdose deaths, especially in the United States and Canada.

Article Title: Elon Musk’s one-word comment on Intel-Nvidia partnership
Article Text:
Elon Musk calls Intel CEO Lip-Bu Tan ‘great’

Nvidia and Intel to develop AI infrastructure and PC products





Nvidia has announced to invest $5 billion in the struggling chipmaker company Intel. Announcing the partnership, Intel CEO Lip-Bu Tan shared a post on X (formerly Twitter) saying “Excited to team up with my good friend Jensen to jointly develop multiple generations of custom data center and PC products!” “Our collaboration brings together the best of @Intel and @Nvidia to benefit customers – and shows how vital x86 architecture and NVLink will be in shaping the future of AI infrastructure and personal computing,” the Intel CEO added.The post caught the attention of Tesla CEO Elon Musk who replied to the post with a single word remark. Responding to Lip-Bu Tan’s post, Musk wrote “Cool”.Commenting on Intel-Nvidia partnership, Epic Games founder and CEO Tim Sweeney wrote on X:“This is awesome. So much potential for integration between CPU, GPU, and data-center-as-supercomputer. How about PCIe with shared memory up to and including virtual memory backed by flash to run leading edge AI models on regular hardware?”.Elon Musk replied to the post, saying “New Intel CEO @LipBuTan1 is great”.In a statement, Nvidia and Intel announced to jointly develop multiple generations of custom data center and PC products that accelerate applications and workloads across hyperscale, enterprise and consumer markets.The companies will focus on seamlessly connecting Nvidia and Intel architectures using Nvidia NVLink — integrating the strengths of Nvidia’s AI and accelerated computing with Intel’s leading CPU technologies and x86 ecosystem to deliver cutting-edge solutions for customers.For data centers, Intel will build Nvidia-custom x86 CPUs that Nvidia will integrate into its AI infrastructure platforms and offer to the market.For personal computing, Intel will build and offer to the market x86 system-on-chips (SOCs) that integrate Nvidia RTX GPU chiplets. These new x86 RTX SOCs will power a wide range of PCs that demand integration of world-class CPUs and GPUs.Nvidia will invest $5 billion in Intel’s common stock at a purchase price of $23.28 per share. The investment is subject to customary closing conditions, including required regulatory approvals.
Article Summary: Intel CEO Lip-Bu Tan shared a post on X (formerly Twitter) saying “Excited to team up with my good friend Jensen to jointly develop multiple generations of custom data center and PC products!” The post caught the attention of Tesla CEO Elon Musk who replied to the post with a single word remark.

Article Title: Nvidia spends over $900 million to buy Enfabrica CEO, licence technology: Here’s why
Article Text:
Why Nvidia is paying millions to AI startup Enfabrica

Recent AI hiring by Meta, Google and others





Nvidia is ramping up its efforts in artificial intelligence (AI) by following a path that Meta and Google recently took — spending millions to secure top AI researchers. The chipmaker, known globally for its powerful GPUs, has reportedly struck a deal with an AI startup to bring its core team on board. According to a report by CNBC, Nvidia has shelled out over $900 million to hire employees of AI startup Enfabrica and its CEO Rochan Sankar. The report cites two people familiar with the matter who said that Nvidia is paying both in cash and stock in the transaction.The decision comes at a time when Nvidia is riding a wave of record growth driven by demand for its chips, which power AI models across the industry. However, the company appears keen to go beyond its role as a hardware supplier. By building an internal pool of researchers, Nvidia is aiming to cement itself as an end-to-end AI leader — combining chips, software, and cutting-edge model development.The AI startup Enfabrica that Nvidia is investing in comes with a rare advantage — a team of specialists trained in building and optimising advanced AI models. Founded in 2019, the AI startup says its technology can connect more than 100,000 GPUs together – a solution that could help Nvidia offer integrated systems around its chips so clusters can effectively serve as a single computer.By absorbing this expertise, Nvidia can accelerate its own projects and reduce reliance on external players.Nvidia has previously invested in Enfabrica as part of a $125 million series B round in 2023. However, the company did not disclose its valuation then.Nvidia’s move mirrors strategies deployed by Meta, Google and other Big Tech firms in recent years. Meta has consistently lured prominent academics with multimillion-dollar pay packages, while Google has built up DeepMind and Google Research by buying startups and bringing in high-profile teams. Companies like OpenAI and Anthropic have also been in the race, intensifying competition and driving salaries to unprecedented levels.
Article Summary: N Nvidia has reportedly shelled out over $900 million to hire employees of AI startup Enfabrica and its CEO Rochan Sankar. The decision comes at a time when Nvidia is riding a wave of record growth driven by demand for its chips, which power AI models across the industry.
